history.content:
Hi, TA here! A lot of the way the class will be run is up in the air currently, as we are waiting for more campus guidelines. Discussions will likely be offered in-person and remotely. There will definitely be an online lab option available. However, we can't guarantee the availability of in-person labs. That will be decided after our lab room gets evaluated for occupancy and safety. 

Remote labs will be brand new this semester, and you won't be able to work with hardware. This style will also require you to install a VM to run simulations and have a computer that's capable of handling that. While you won't have to deal with pesky hardware bugs, you'll also be the first students to try these labs so may encounter other (potentially more frustrating) bugs instead--and ones that TAs haven't seen before so may need more time debugging and helping. We are trying to keep the content across both styles of lab the same, but remote restrictions just won't allow us to do certain tasks that involve physically being with a robot.

I can't speak to the worth of delaying next year. Honestly, given how poorly America as a whole is handling the virus situation and safety/health guidelines traditionally held for vaccines, we might still be stuck in this style of learning for a year. I personally came from a background of competitive robotics, so I loved being able to work physically with the robots and build more physical intuition with the robots. However, I have full faith in our staff to be able to provide an equally compelling, enriching semester remotely--even if it's fulfilling in a different way. We've been hard at work all summer to make this possible! 

Hope that helps!

children.subject: I wouldn't be comfortable promising that. Each lab--remote or not--will need to be adequately staffed, and that's ultimately down to how big our budget is.

Is it also reasonable to ask at this time what the waitlist will be like? I am number 2 on the waitlist, and there seem to be 9 more people. Since instruction will most likely have to include a remote option, is it safe to assume we can get in?

history.content: On classes.berkeley.edu, EECS C106A is currently listed with the instruction mode as "Flex--See class note details". Where can I find these note details? Also, what will be the differences between content in in-person labs vs content in remote labs? Would an in-person experience be worth delaying this class until next year?
history.subject: EECS C106A Flex Instruction Mode
